_prev_prog_3.MS_OtherType: Each tank and the pump house have foam fire suppresion.  The tank farm area is covered by foam and water cannons.
_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: The fire detection and alarm system has heat sensors in each tank.
_prev_prog_3.Description:
The natural gasoline system consists of a truck receiving station, two storage tanks at ambient temperature and pressure, and a transfer pump to meter the product into a mixing station.

The natural gasoline storage tanks have clay lined earthen dikes for secondary containment.  The fire protection system consists of heat sensors in each tank, foam fire suppression in each tank, with foam and water cannons around the perimeter of the dike.  The fire system conforms to NFPA standards 11, 13, 16 and 30.  Insurance related standards for this area are FM Global 7-32 and 7-88.  The area is classified as Class 1 Division 2 for electrical equipment.  

A risk-consulting contractor typically conducts semiannual third party audits of the facility, including the natural gasoline system.  Equipment in this system is included in the leak detection and repair (LDAR) program as required by 40 CFR 60 subpart VV.  The natural gasoline tanks are inspected according to the schedule in the facility?s Spill Prevention Control and Countermeasure (SPCC) plan.

Standard operating procedures have been developed and written to safely transfer and store the natural gasoline.  Indicators for remote tank levels are verified quarterly.  Automatic valves and interlocks provide secondary protection from overfilling the tanks or running the pump without flow or grounding protection.

Employees at this facility use the ADM Behavioral Safety Program for a system of reporting safety observations, auditing safe work practices and investigating incidents for corrective actions.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary
Risk Management Plan for Natural Gasoline
ADM Corn Processing
Walhalla, ND

Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies:
It is the policy of the Archer Daniels Midland Company (ADM) Corn Processing Facility, Walhalla, ND to implement the requirements of the Risk Management Program in accordance with the USEPA regulations under 40 CFR Part 68.  The objective is to prevent an explosion/fire or release of natural gasoline and to minimize the potential impact to ADM?s employees, the public and the environment.  This objective will be accomplished by utilizing good operating procedures, maintaining a preventative maintenance program, providing appropriate training to employees and coordinating response activities with local emergency responders.

Facility description and regulated substances handled:
ADM Corn Processing at Walhalla is located on 111 acres approximately 1.5 miles east of the city of Walhalla, ND.  The primary activity of the facility is processing corn to manufacture fuel ethanol and distiller?s grain.

In this Risk Management Plan (RMP), ADM has included a program for its denaturant used in the production of fuel ethanol.  The denaturant (natural gasoline) used at the facilities generally has a National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) flammability hazard rating of less than 4 and is exempt from the RMP according to 40 CFR 68.115(b)(2).  However, due to the potential variability in the make-up of this additive, it is possible that ADM will receive material that has a flammability rating of 4.  Therefore, ADM has included provisions in the RMP for managing the denaturant as a precautionary measure.  The regulated substances found in natural gasoline are n-pentane & isopentane. 

The main components of the natural gasoline system are a truck unloading station, an unloading pump, two storage tanks, a transfer pump and associated valves and piping.  Natural gasoline is received by truck only.

General accidental release

prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps:
The key concepts in this facility's prevention program are employee participation, analysis of hazards, operating procedures and safe work practices, personnel training, maintenance and mechanical integrity programs, and contractor programs.  

Five-year accident history:
The facility had no reportable accidents in the last five years.

The emergency response program:

Emergency response at this facility is coordinated with ADM personnel and the Pembina County Emergency Planning Committee so that in the event of an accident, immediate emergency response measures will be implemented.  The facility maintains a written Environmental/Emergency Response Plan to deal with prevention of and response to accidental releases of hazardous materials.

Planned changes to improve safety:

There were also several recommended actions that were completed as a result of the process hazard analyses.  These included procedural changes for maintenance of affected equipment and transfer of product and installation of interlocks between pumps and valves.

ADM will continue to evaluate and implement changes when necessary to improve safety at the Walhalla facility.
